description.summary: Claimed communication with spirits via electronic recordings. Practitioners record in allegedly haunted locations, then play back recordings searching for 'voices' in static or noise that were not audible during recording.
description.full: Electronic Voice Phenomena (EVP) is the claimed communication with spirits through electronic audio recordings. The method involves recording in allegedly haunted locations using digital recorders or specialized equipment, then playing back the recording to find 'voices' in background noise or static that were not heard during the original recording. The practice developed in the 1950s-1960s, notably by Friedrich Jürgenson (1959) and Konstantin Raudive (who claimed over 100,000 recordings). EVP is classified by clarity: Class A (clear, all listeners hear), Class B (some interpretation needed), Class C (heavy interpretation required). Modern ghost hunting popularized 'spirit boxes' (radio frequency scanners). Scientific consensus attributes EVP to pareidolia (hearing patterns in noise) and radio interference, with no verified spirit communication. Despite scientific explanation, EVP remains popular in paranormal investigation and appears regularly on ghost hunting television programs.

Moderately clear, most listeners agree on content with some prompting
Unclear, heavy interpretation required, listeners often disagree

Radio frequency scanner rapidly sweeping stations
recording_methods.notes: Picks up random radio fragments; controversy over validity

Responses to questions asked during recording

range.description: Global phenomenon, practiced wherever ghost hunting and paranormal investigation occur
range.concentration: Western countries with strong paranormal investigation culture (USA, UK, Germany)

Ghost hunting TV shows popularize EVP widely

origins.cultural_roots: Developed in mid-20th century as technology became accessible; combines spiritualism tradition with electronic recording technology
origins.earliest_accounts: Friedrich Jürgenson (Swedish filmmaker) accidentally recorded 'voices' while taping bird songs in 1959
origins.folklore_connections: Extension of spiritualism movement's desire to communicate with the dead using available technology

timeline.significance: Swedish filmmaker discovers unexplained voices on bird song recordings
Latvian psychologist conducts extensive EVP experiments, claims 100,000+ recordings
Brings EVP to wider English-speaking audience
No convincing evidence found in controlled conditions
Shows like Ghost Adventures, Ghost Hunters make EVP mainstream

history.modern_era: EVP remains core technique in paranormal investigation despite lack of scientific validation. Digital technology has made recording easier; 'spirit boxes' and specialized apps claim to facilitate communication. Scientific consensus remains that EVP is pareidolia and radio interference.

recordings.name: Raudive Voices
recordings.description: Over 100,000 claimed recordings by Konstantin Raudive
recordings.analysis: Scientific testing found no evidence; likely pareidolia and radio interference

scientific_tests.name: Pye Records Test (1970s)
scientific_tests.description: Professional audio engineers tested Raudive's claims in controlled conditions
scientific_tests.result: No convincing evidence of paranormal voices
scientific_tests.analysis: Found radio interference and pareidolia effects

paranormal.name: Spirit Communication
paranormal.description: Deceased spirits manipulate electronic equipment to leave voice messages

paranormal.name: Quantum Consciousness
paranormal.description: Consciousness after death exists in quantum state and can affect electronic devices

scientific.name: Pareidolia (Audio)
scientific.description: Human brain seeks patterns in noise; we 'hear' words in random sounds
evidence_cited: Listeners hear different 'words' in same recording

scientific.name: Radio Interference
scientific.description: Electronic devices pick up stray radio signals, CB radio, walkie-talkies, etc.
evidence_cited: Spirit boxes literally scan radio frequencies

scientific.name: Confirmation Bias
scientific.description: Investigators find what they expect; interpret ambiguous sounds as desired messages

scientific.name: Audio Artifacts
scientific.description: Recording equipment creates artifacts, compression noise, electrical interference

paranormal_investigation.significance: EVP is fundamental technique in modern ghost hunting
paranormal_investigation.practice: Record in allegedly haunted locations, ask questions, play back audio searching for responses

popular_culture.influence: Television shows have made EVP one of most recognized paranormal investigation techniques

scientific_perspective.consensus: No verified spirit communication; explained by pareidolia and radio interference
key_findings: Radio interference common in electronic devices
